(5) Upon completion of the installation, required inspection, maintenance, and any necessary repairs to the septic system, the contractor shall certify that the work was conducted and completed in accordance with the accepted professional standards and practices and that the system is in good repair and proper working order by completing a Septic System Inspection and Compliance Statement. The contractor's Septic System Inspection and Compliance Statement must be accompanied by the detailed contractor's receipt for septic system services rendered. The property owner shall certify that he or she has had all septic system components, including the field lines, inspected, the septic tank or tanks pumped and any necessary repairs completed. The property owner or owners shall bear the responsibility for securing all documentation and completed forms related to compliance with this section and for providing those forms to the city clerk no later than the service interval deadline. (6) With exception of the detailed receipt for services rendered, all completed forms referenced herein must be submitted as original documents to the city clerk on forms acceptable to the city clerk. (Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-102, 10-6-2005; Ord. No. O-187-15, 7-1-2015) Sec. 58-3. - Service requirements; extensions. (a) Requests for extensions to any deadline or time period identified within this chapter should be directed to the city clerk or his or her designee in a timely manner so as not to violate the design of this chapter. A property owner's intent to petition the city clerk or his or her designee for an extension on an impending deadline will not be deemed an excuse for failure to comply with the time frames herein. (b) Once a property owner's petition has been taken under consideration by the city clerk or his or her designee, however, no penalty or further violation will accrue until the matter is decided, unless such violation is identified as creating a threat to public health and safety. (c) In the event that the septic system malfunctions during such time as a petition for extension is before the city clerk or his or her designee, the property owner must immediately remedy the septic system malfunction and withdraw the petition from further consideration. (Ord. No. O-90-08, 7-26-2008) Editor's note— Ord. No.O-90-08, adopted Jul. 26, 2008, repealed § 58-3, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 58-3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-103, adopted Oct. 6, 2005. Sec. 58-4. - Record maintenance. The city clerk shall maintain the completed forms, transmittal letters, violations and any related septic system information with the city records. (Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-104, 10-6-2005) Sec. 58-5. - Malfunctioning systems. (a) An on-site sewage disposal system shall be deemed to be a malfunctioning system if sewage is allowed to discharge or flow from it on said property, into any storm drain, stream, water body, gutter, street, roadway or public place, or if sewage discharges from said system to the surface or subsurface of any property so as to create a nuisance or a condition detrimental to health. Substantial backflow from the leaching area (absorption lines/field lines) into the tank during a tank pump-out shall also be considered an indication of a malfunctioning system as determined by a registered and certified service person employed by a septic system service company registered with the county. (b) In addition, any and all parts of a septic system that are found by a registered and certified service person employed by a septic system service company registered with the county to be damaged, misaligned or missing, such as but not limited to a cracked lid, missing "T" or misaligned outflow line, shall constitute a malfunctioning system. (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter, all property owners with septic systems or other approved, on-site waste management systems shall be responsible for correcting the malfunctioning of such systems within 30 days from receipt of written notification, which notice shall communicate the specifics of the malfunction. Reporting of repairs shall be consistent with section 58-2. (Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-105, 10-6-2005) Sec. 58-6. - Violations. (a) Failure to have required inspections and servicing performed before the deadline provided in the notice for service due letter, and according to section 58-2 shall constitute a violation. Failure to submit the Septic System Inspection and Compliance Statement and copy of the septic service contractor's receipt for services rendered according to section 58-2(5) shall constitute a separate violation of said section. Each violation is subject to penalty. (b) Violations pertaining to required inspections and servicing and/or reporting may be punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for 60 days, or both. Violations pertaining to required inspections and servicing accrue every 90 days and are deemed separate violations of this chapter, until such time as the requirements established in section 58-2 are met. (c) Violations of section 58-5 may occur if necessary repairs to the malfunctioning system are not conducted within 30 days, not reported properly, or are not performed by a certified service person. Please review sections 58-2(2), (4)—(6) and 58-5. (d) Violations pertaining to malfunctioning systems may be punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for 60 days, or both. In addition, malfunctioning septic systems must be repaired within 30 days from the date of notification of violation. Failure to correct the malfunctioning system by the end of the 30 th day shall be construed to be a separate violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. O-83-08, 5-15-2008; Ord. No. O-187-15, 7-1-2015) Editor's note— Ord. No. O-83-08, adopted May 15, 2008, repealed § 58-6, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 58-6 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-106, adopted Oct. 6, 2005. Sec. 58-7. - Basis for extensions. Extensions to modify the five-year reporting and servicing requirement as specified in section 58-2 may be granted under certain conditions. (1) The owner of a septic system may seek an administrative extension based upon official extension guidelines. If the information provided on the completed petition for extension form indicates that said septic system can be serviced at an interval longer than five years, and the owner certifies the information on the form is accurate, then the petition for extension may be submitted for approval by the city clerk or his or her designee. Extensions to the maximum service interval for required septic system service are valid for a period of three years, subject to renewal upon re-qualification and shall be limited to a total maximum service interval of 11 years when combined with the original 5-year interval. No extension shall be granted in the event that the most recent statement of inspection and service indicates existing or potential issues, damage or disrepair or if the information submitted is determined to be inaccurate. Granted extensions shall not convey with changes in ownership or rental occupancy. (2) Examples of consideration for an extension may include, but are not limited to: a. Usage significantly less than capacity of system; b. Nonfull-time occupancy; and c. Advanced technology septic system. (Ord. No. O-90-08, 7-26-2008; Ord. No. O-187-15, 7-1-2015) Editor's note— Ord. No.O-90-08, adopted Jul. 26, 2008, repealed § 58-7, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 58-7 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-107, adopted Oct. 6, 2005. Sec. 58-8. - Duties of city clerk. The city clerk shall maintain blank forms, completed forms, transmittal letters, violations and any related septic system information with the city records. In addition, the city clerk or his or her designee shall be responsible for review and approval/denial of septic system service and inspection extension requests. (Ord. No. O-90-08, 7-26-2008) Editor's note— Ord. No.O-90-08, adopted Jul. 26, 2008, repealed § 58-8, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, § 58-8 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-26-05b, § 17-108, adopted Oct. 6, 2005.

div.head: Chapter 62 - SIGNS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, adopted June 21, 2012, repealed Ch. 62, §§ 62-1—6-32, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, Ch. 62 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. Charter reference— Incorporation and powers, article 1: powers and construction, § 1.12; administrative affairs, article 3: boards, commissions, and authorities, § 3.11; city clerk, § 3.13; judicial branch, article 4: jurisdiction, § 4.13; certiorari, § 4.14; finance, article 6: occupation and business taxes, § 6.12; regulatory fees, § 6.13.
Sec. 62-1. - Findings, purpose and intent. (a) The mayor and couuncil find that signs are an important and effective medium through which persons may convey a variety of messages, both commercial and non-commercial in character. The mayor and couuncil further find that the regulation of location, size, placement, height and other relevant physical characteristics of signs and sign structures is necessary to enable the public to locate goods, services, facilities and properties within the City of Berkeley Lake without difficulty or confusion; to improve the general aesthetic of the city; and to protect the value of properties therein. Such regulation is also necessary to facilitate and aid in the identification and location of homes and businesses in the city in the event of police, fire or other emergencies and to avoid confusion and delay in response to such emergencies. Left unregulated, signs can become a substantial threat to public safety by way of traffic or pedestrian hazards and a detriment to property values and the city's overall public welfare as an aesthetic nuisance. The mayor and couuncil also find that the regulations contained herein directly advance the stated purposes and such regulations are narrowly tailored to serve the city's interests. (b) The city's purpose in enacting these regulations is to: (1) Balance the right of persons to convey their messages through signs with the right of the public to be protected from the adverse effects of the unrestricted proliferation of signs. (2) Enhance the economic health of existing and future businesses and industries within the city by promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs advertising goods and services. (3) Promote and protect the public health, safety and general welfare. (4) Provide for signs which are compatible with their surroundings. (5) Promote and protect the unique natural beauty and aesthetic qualities of the city (6) Reduce the probability of traffic or pedestrian accidents by restricting visual obstructions or distractions caused by signs or lights. (7) Create a comprehensive and balanced system of sign control that ensures the fair and consistent enforcement of the regulations and the proper maintenance, structural soundness, safety, appearance and attractiveness of signs and sign structures. (8) Further the objectives of the city's comprehensive plan, which is expressly incorporated herein. (c) Promote the state purposes of the city's zoning ordinance, which are expressly incorporated herein.These regulations are intended to ensure the protection of free speech rights guaranteed by the United State[s] Constitution and Georgia Constitution. They are not intended to and do not restrict the content of sign messages. These regulations do not apply to signs located on public property, including rights-of way. The placement, regulation and enforcement of signs on public lands, including rights-of-way, shall be in accordance with the laws, rules and regulations of the State of Georgia, Gwinnett County and the City of Berkeley Lake, as applicable. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-2. - Definitions. (a) Except as specifically defined herein, the words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them. Words and phrases not defined in this chapter but defined in Chapter 78 of the city's Code of Ordinances shall have the meaning set forth in Chapter 78. All other words and phrases shall be construed to have the meaning given by common and ordinary usage and shall be interpreted within the context of the sentence, paragraph and section in which they occur. Words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. Words used in the present tense include the future as the context may require. The word "city" means the City of Berkeley Lake, Georgia. The term "city council" means the elected governing body of the City of Berkeley Lake, Georgia. The word "shall" is always mandatory and never discretionary. The word "may" is permissive. The word "person" includes the terms "individuals", "firms", "partnerships", "corporations", "associations", "governmental bodies" and all other legal entities. The word "lot" includes the words "plot" or "parcel." The word "erected" includes the words "constructed", "moved", "located" or "relocated." (b) Land use categories referred to in this chapter are defined herein for the purpose of regulating signs. The use in this chapter of the term "property" relative to a land use category includes both developed and undeveloped properties, while the term "use" means a property that is developed, occupied or otherwise in operation under the land use category. The land use categories are as follow: Agricultural means a property used primarily for the cultivation of crops, dairying or the raising or keeping of livestock, or a vacant property zoned or offered for sale or lease for such purpose. Commercial means a property occupied primarily by one or more business establishments that are engaged in the sale of goods; the provision of personal, professional, business, entertainment or other commercial services; the management of a business enterprise; or the provision of temporary housing to the traveling public (such as a motel); or a vacant property zoned or offered for sale or lease for such purposes. Industrial means a property occupied primarily by one or more business establishments that are engaged in the fabrication, manufacture, production, storage or distribution of durable or nondurable goods, or a vacant property zoned or offered for sale or lease for such purpose. Institutional means a property occupied by a private, nonprofit religious, recreational, educational or philanthropic organization, club or semipublic institution. Multifamily residential means a property occupied primarily by one or more residential buildings containing three or more dwelling units, or a vacant property zoned or offered for sale or lease for such purposes. Single- and two-family residential means a property occupied primarily by one or more single-family dwellings or duplex dwellings, or a vacant property zoned or offered for sale or lease for such purpose. (c) The following words and phrases relating to signs have specific meanings as used in this chapter: Abandoned sign means cessation for a period of six months of the use of a sign by either the owner of the sign or the occupant of the property on which the sign is placed, or through the removal or relocation of the previous occupant of the property, or a sign that has ceased to be used for a period of six months through the removal of its copy or the deterioration of its copy through lack of maintenance, but excluding temporary or short-term periods of remodeling, refurbishment or maintenance of the sign. Aggregate sign area means the sum total of the sign areas of any and all signs on a given lot, including principal and miscellaneous freestanding and wall signs. Project entrance signs, street address numbers meeting the specifications of Section 62-4(4), flags and banners are excluded from the determination of aggregate sign area. Animated sign means a sign that uses movement of any part by any means (manual, mechanical, air or wind-driven) or changes of lighting to depict action or to create a special effect or scene. This includes signs that flash, blink, flicker, scroll, fade, rotate or revolve to transition between messages but does not include flags or banners or other allowed signs of lightweight material that may incidentally shift position under wind pressure. Awning means a roof-like cover which projects from the wall of a building for the purpose of shielding a doorway, or window from the elements. Awnings are often made of fabric or flexible plastic supported by a rigid frame, and may be retracted into the face of the building. Awning sign. See Building sign. Banner means a sign, other than a flag, with or without characters, letters, illustrations or ornamentation applied to cloth, paper, flexible plastic, vinyl or fabric, including canvas, which is intended to be hung either with a frame or without a frame. Neither awning nor canopy signs are considered banners. Building sign means a sign that in any manner is fastened to, projects from, or is placed or painted upon the exterior wall, window, door, or roof of a building. The term "building sign" includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Awning sign means a sign imposed, mounted or painted upon an awning. (2) Canopy sign means a sign affixed to, superimposed upon, or painted on any canopy, such that the sign is mounted in such a manner that a continuous face with the canopy is formed. (3) Mansard sign means a sign imposed, mounted or painted upon a mansard and not extending above the top of the mansard. (4) Marquee sign means any sign painted on or attached flat to the face of a marquee. (5) Parapet sign means a sign imposed, mounted or painted on a parapet and not extending above the top of the parapet. (6) Projecting sign means a sign affixed perpendicularly to a wall and extending more than 12 inches horizontally from the surface of such wall. (7) Roof sign means a sign projecting over the coping of a flat roof, or over the ridge of a gambrel, hip or gable roof, and supported by or attached to the roof. (8) Under-canopy sign means a sign attached to the underside of a marquee or canopy and suspended over a sidewalk, either public or private. (9) Wall or fascia sign means a sign that is fastened directly to or is placed or painted directly upon the exterior wall of a building, with the sign face parallel to the wall, protruding from the surface of the wall no more than 18 inches and not extending above or beyond the wall to which it is attached. (10) Window sign means a sign that is placed on or behind a windowpane or glass door and oriented to be viewed from outside the building. Canopy means a permanent roof-like structure projecting from a building and open on at least one side for the purpose of shielding a pedestrian walkway from the elements, or a freestanding roof-like structure supported by columns intended to shield a vehicular driveway or service area from the elements. Changeable copy sign includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Automatic changeable copy sign means a sign on which the copy may be changed at intervals on a lamp bank/matrix by electronic process or by remote control, including devices utilizing light bulbs, Liquid Crystal Diodes (LCD), Light Emitting Diodes (LED) or fiber optics, (e.g., electrical or electronic time and temperature units, video displays, electronic billboards). The term "copy" means words, numbers, symbols and/or pictorial representations. (2) Manual changeable copy sign means a sign that is capable of changing the content, position or format of word messages or other displays on the sign face by the manual or mechanical manipulation of a matrix of movable discs, panels, light apertures or other methods. Channeled letters (internally illuminated letters) includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Internally channeled letters means letters or other symbols with recessed surfaces designed to accommodate incandescent bulbs or luminous tubing. (2) Reverse channeled letters means letters or other symbols with raised surfaces designed to be lighted from behind by incandescent bulbs or luminous tubing. Double-faced sign means a sign structure with two sign faces that are parallel (back-to-back) or that form an angle to one another of no more than 60 degrees, where each sign face is designed to be seen from a different direction. Festoons means strings of ribbons, tinsel, small flags, pennants, streamers, pinwheels, or other devices or long narrow strips of fabric, plastic, or other pliable material designed to move in the wind. Flag means any fabric or bunting containing distinctive colors, patterns, words, emblems or logos used as a symbol of a government or other entity or organization. Freestanding sign means a sign supported by structures or supports that are placed on or anchored in the ground and that is wholly independent of any building or other structure for support. The term "freestanding sign" includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Pole, pylon or stanchion sign means a free-standing sign that is mounted on a freestanding pole, pylon, stanchion, columns, or similar supports such that the bottom of the sign face or lowest sign module is not in contact with the ground. (2) Monument sign means a freestanding sign forming a solid, monolithic structure from the ground to the top of the sign. Frontage, building, means the width in linear feet of the front exterior wall of a particular establishment. Frontage, road, means the width in linear feet of each lot where it abuts the right-of-way of any public street. Holiday means a day fixed by law or custom commemorating an event or honoring a person. Illegal sign means any sign that was erected in violation of the laws of the controlling jurisdiction as they existed at the time the sign was established, including signs installed without a permit and signs that were not installed in conformance with a properly issued permit. Illuminated signs include but are not limited to the following: (1) Internally illuminated means illuminated by an artificial light source from within the sign structure and radiating outward toward the viewer, usually projected through a transparent or translucent sign face. (2) Externally illuminated means illuminated only by an artificial light source that is external to, and independent of, the sign structure, and the illumination radiates toward the message area away from the viewer. (3) Halo illumination means illumination where the source of light is external and integral to the sign structure; where the resultant illumination radiates toward the viewer, is interrupted by the opaque sign structure, letters, or symbols, and back lights the message area. (4) Neon sign means an illuminated sign composed of exposed and visible tubes filled with neon gas, including signs of similar appearance but illuminated by other gases similar to neon. Incidental sign means a small sign, emblem, or decal no larger than two square feet located on a building or structure. Such signs are normally located on doors, windows, and gas pumps, and are generally not readily visible or legible from public rights-of-way. Inflatable sign. A sign or similar device that is intended to be expanded by pressurized air or other gas or by mechanical fan for its proper display or support. Internally illuminated letters. See Channeled letters. Mansard means a steeply sloped, roof-like facade architecturally similar to a building wall. Mansard sign. See Building sign. Marquee means a permanent roof-like structure or canopy of rigid materials supported by and extending from the facade of a building. Marquee sign. See Building sign. Minimum front setback means the minimum distance required by the zoning district as applied to a property between an adjoining street and the facade of a principal building on the property. Miscellaneous sign means any sign other than the principal sign or an incidental sign on a property or building, as applicable. Monument sign. See Freestanding sign. Multi-faced sign means a single sign structure consisting of three or more sign faces that are separated from each other at their nearest point by no more than three feet, whether or not all faces contain some message. Sign faces on a single sign structure that are separated by more than three feet are treated as separate signs. Non-conforming sign means any sign that was lawfully permitted by the jurisdiction of record at the time and/or was legal at the time of its establishment but does not conform to the provisions of this chapter. Pennant means any lightweight plastic, fabric or similar material designed to move in the wind; pennants are often suspended from a rope, wire, or string in series. The term "pennant" shall not include a banner as defined in this chapter. Permanent sign means any sign that is not temporary. Planned center means a building or group of buildings occupied by two or more retail stores, service establishments, offices, industries or any other businesses or mixed uses that do not share common space, which is located on a property that is in common ownership or condominium ownership. Buildings that are occupied by two or more businesses that share common space, such as but not limited to a branch bank in a grocery store, a fast-food restaurant in a merchandise store, or booths in a flea market, are not considered planned centers. Pole or pylon sign. See Freestanding sign. Portable sign means a sign designed to be transported or easily relocated and not permanently attached to the ground, such as but not limited to the following: (1) A sign designed to be temporarily placed upon the ground and not anchored to it as otherwise required by the building code; (2) A sign mounted on a trailer, with or without wheels; or (3) For the purposes of this chapter, sidewalk signs, sandwich board signs, banners and pole banners as prescribed herein are not considered portable signs. Principal building sign means the main, predominant or largest permanent sign on an individual wall of a building or tenant space. Principal freestanding sign means the main, predominant and largest freestanding sign on a property. Project entrance sign means a permanent freestanding sign located at a discernible entrance from a public or private road into a multi-family development, or into a development containing multiple lots or buildings, such as but not limited to a particular residential or commercial subdivision, a business center, office park or industrial park or a mixed use planned center. Projecting sign. See Building sign. Roof sign. See Building sign. Sidewalk or sandwich sign means a moveable sign not permanently secured or attached to the ground or surface upon which it is located, designed to be used on a sidewalk or pedestrian way immediately adjacent to a building or structure. Sign means any structure, display, or device that is used to advertise, identify, direct, or attract attention to a business, institution, organization, person, idea, product, service, event, or location by any means, including words, letters, figures, design characteristics, symbols, logos, fixtures, colors, movement, or illumination. Sign area means the total area upon which message(s) is (are) or can be displayed and calculated as the area of the smallest regular square, rectangle, triangle, circle or combination thereof encompassing the entire sign, inclusive of any border or trim but excluding the base, apron and other structural members. For double faced signs, the side with the largest area shall be used to calculate the sign area Sign face means that part or display surface of a sign where words, letters, figures, symbols, logos, fixtures, colors, or other design elements are or may be located in order to convey the message, idea, or intent for which the sign has been erected or placed. Sign height means the distance in vertical feet from the elevation of the adjacent dedicated public street, edge of pavement, to the highest point of the sign structure. For property with an elevation higher than the adjacent public street, the height shall be measured from ground level at base of sign to the highest point of the sign structure. The ground shall not be altered for the sole purpose of providing additional sign height. Sign structure means all elements of a freestanding sign, including the sign face, background, or decorative elements related to the presentation or support of the sign's message, and the structural supports. Swinging or projecting sign means a sign projecting perpendicularly from the outside wall of the building upon which it is located. See Projecting sign under Building sign. Temporary signs shall mean any sign not permanently affixed to the ground or other permanent structure and designed and intended to be displayed for a limited period of time. Tenant means a natural person, business or other entity that occupies land or buildings by ownership, under a lease, or through payment of rent; an occupant, inhabitant, or dweller of a place. Under-canopy sign. See Building sign. Vehicular sign means any sign placed on, mounted on, painted on or affixed to a motor vehicle, freight, flatbed or storage trailer or other conveyance when same are placed or parked in such a manner as to be viewed or intended to be viewed from the public right-of-way, except that this definition shall not apply when: (1) Such conveyances are actively being used to load, transport or unload persons, goods or services in the normal course of business; (2) Such conveyances are parked in an inconspicuous area, such as but not limited to a loading dock or to the side or rear of a building away from the street; or (3) Such conveyances are actively being used for storage of construction materials for, and on the same lot with, a bona fide construction project for which building and other applicable permits have been issued and where construction is underway, and provided said conveyances are located within designated storage areas. Wall sign. See Building sign. Window sign. See Building sign. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-3. - General provisions. (a) Applicability. The regulations and requirements of this chapter apply to all signs erected within the corporate limits of the city that are or are intended to be viewed from a public right-of-way, a private street or adjacent property, except as otherwise exempt under this section. The provisions of this chapter do not apply to any sign not visible from public or private thoroughfares or adjacent properties and any sign within a business, office, mall, or totally enclosed area. (b) Compliance. All erection, construction, enlargement, moving, altering or converting of signs in the city shall be performed in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (c) Exclusions. The following are not considered signs and are excluded from all restrictions and regulations imposed by this chapter: (1) Words and/or graphics on products that are an integral part of the product, the product's original packaging, and product dispensers (such as but not limited to soft drink machines and gasoline pumps) are not considered to be signs and are exempt from these sign regulations. Product containers intended only for the storage of products are not exempt from these regulations. (2) A building design, color, architectural element or motif that is associated with a particular establishment or organization but which conveys no message is not considered to be a sign and is exempt from these sign regulations. (d) Owner's consent required . No sign regulated by this chapter may be permitted or placed on property without the consent of the property's owner or authorized agent. Should it be determined that a sign was erected on a lot pursuant to an alleged agent's incorrect representation that the record owner of the lot in fact gave permission for the erection of a sign, the permit for such sign shall be revoked as provided in section 62-6. (e) Sign maintenance . All signs shall be maintained in good condition as to present a neat and orderly appearance. The city may, after giving due notice, issue a citation to any permittee or property owner for any sign which show gross neglect or becomes dilapidated. Such due notice shall be in writing, shall clearly identify the sign and its location, and shall state that the sign has not been properly maintained. The city shall allow the permittee or property owner ten business days from the date of the notice days in which to rectify the condition or remove the dilapidated sign before issuing a citation. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-4. - Exemptions from permit requirements. Each of the following types of signs is allowed on any property and is exempt from the permit requirements imposed by this chapter: (1) Official signs. Signs placed by or at the direction of a governmental body, governmental agency, board of education, public utility or public authority pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 32-6-50 et seq. or any other law. As provided by O.C.G.A. § 32-6-51, such signs are authorized within all rights-of-way or other properties controlled by such governmental body, agency, board of education, public utility or public authority and at such other locations as a governmental body, governmental agency, public utility or public authority may direct. (2) Incidental signs. Small signs as defined in this chapter of no more than two square feet, provided that the aggregate of all such signs on a property may not exceed 16 square feet unless a larger aggregate area is required by law or government regulation. (3) Miscellaneous signs. Freestanding or wall signs not more than 2.25 square feet in area. (4) Street addresses. Numerals displayed exclusively to indicate the assigned street address of a property where no more than four inches in height on single and two-family residential properties and ten inches in height for all other land use categories. (5) Window signs. Individual or aggregate window signsnot exceeding 20 percent of the available window area per building elevation. (6) Flags. Flags meeting the standards of Section 62-8. (7) Single and two-family residential. Except for residentialproject entrance signs, signs on single and two-family properties shall not require sign permits. (8) Sidewalk and sandwich signs. Sidewalk and sandwich signs meeting the standards of Section 62-14(c). (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-5. - Prohibited signs. Unless otherwise excluded under section 62-3(d), the following types of signs are prohibited: (a) Animated and flashing signs. Signs (excluding automatic changeable copy signs) that flash, blink, rotate, revolve, or have moving parts or visible bulbs, and signs containing reflective elements that sparkle in the sunlight or otherwise simulate illumination during daylight hours. (b) Attached and painted signs. Signs that are painted on or attached to curbs, utility poles, or trees, rocks or other natural features. (c) Courtesy benches, trash cans, etc. Courtesy benches, trash cans, and similar devices on which a sign is displayed. (d) Dilapidated signs. Signs that are dilapidated or in such condition as to create a hazard, nuisance or to be unsafe or fail to comply with any provision of the building code. (e) Obscene signs. Obscene signs, as defined by the state at O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80, as amended. (f) Obstructions. No sign shall obstruct any fire escape, window, door, or opening usable for fire prevention or suppression, or prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof. No sign shall extend above a parapet wall, be affixed to a fire escape, or interfere with any opening required for ventilation. No sign shall interfere with road or highway visibility or obstruct or otherwise interfere with the orderly movement of traffic or pedestrians. No sign shall pose a hazard to traffic or pedestrians due to structural deficiencies of such sign. (g) Pole or pylon signs. Signs meeting the definition of pole or pylon as defined in this chapter are not allowed as principal freestanding signs. (h) Portable signs. Signs meeting the definition of a portable sign pursuant to this chapter. (i) Private signs placed on public property. Any sign posted or erected on public rights-of-way or any other public property except as authorized by the governmental body, agency or public authority having jurisdiction over such property. (j) Roof signs. Roof signs, including signs painted or adhered on roofs, are not allowed. This prohibition does not apply to the fascia portion of a mansard roof, or to the face of a parapet wall, provided that the sign must not extend above the top of the mansard roof or parapet wall. (k) Signs advertising illegal activity. Signs that advertise an activity illegal under state or federal law. (l) Signs imitating public warning or traffic devices. (1) Any sign that displays intermittent lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or in police, fire, ambulance, or rescue vehicles, and any sign that uses the words "stop," "go," "slow," "caution," "danger," "warning" or other message or content in a manner that might mislead or confuse a driver. (2) Any sign that uses the words, slogans, dimensional shape or size, or colors of governmental traffic signs. (3) No red, green, and yellow illuminated sign shall be permitted within 300 feet of any traffic light. (m) Sound or smoke emitting signs. A sign that emits or utilizes in any manner any sound capable of being detected on any traveled road or highway by a person with normal hearing, or a sign that emits smoke, vapor or odors. (n) Vehicular signs. Any sign that meets the definition of a vehicular sign as defined in this chapter. (o) Window signs. Window signs on residential properties and individual or aggregate window signs exceeding 20 percent of the window area per building elevation for all other uses. (p) LED strips. Exposed LED strip lights when used as a sign on buildings or free-standing sign structures. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012; Ord. No. O-179-14, § 1, 12-18-2014) Sec. 62-6. - Sign permits. (a) Permit required . Except as exempted from obtaining a permit, all persons desiring to post, install, erect, display, expand, relocate or substantially change a sign regulated by this chapter within the city, shall first obtain a sign permit and all other permits required for the desired structure in accordance with city ordinances. A change in the copy of a sign shall not constitute a substantial change. However, a change in the mode of message conveyance (i.e. from screen-print panel to LED) shall be considered a substantial change requiring a sign permit. (b) Application requirements . Applications for sign permits, along with the non-refundable application fee, shall be submitted by the sign owner or the owner's agent to the city clerk or designee on the form furnished by the city. Only complete applications will be accepted. Applications shall include the following: (1) The street address of the property upon which the sign is to be located. In the absence of a street address, the Parcel Identification Number as assigned by the Gwinnett County Tax Assessor shall be given. (2) The names(s) and address(es) of all owner's of the real property upon which the sign is to be located. (3) The name, address, contact information and occupational tax certificate number and issuing jurisdiction of the sign contractor/installer. (4) Written consent of the owner or owner's agent specifically granting permission for the placement of the sign as proposed. (5) The type of sign, height, face area and total cost of sign construction or installation. (6) The aggregate face area of all signs by type on the property. (7) For free-standing signs, a site plan, drawn to scale, showing the location of the proposed sign in relation to property and right-of-way lines (or edge of pavement, as appropriate), acreage of the parcel, location of driveways and parking spaces, public or private easements, building locations and gross floor area of buildings or floor area occupied by the subject owner or tenant. (8) For building signs, a to-scale drawing or photo-simulation of the building face upon which the proposed sign is to be installed showing the placement of the sign upon the building, dimensions of the wall and sign and its height from ground level. (9) Construction and/or fabrication details of the proposed sign, including certification as to conformance with all structural and wind-load resistive standards of the building code by a qualified structural engineer, or prepared using standard drawings prepared by a structural engineer or other qualified professional meeting, or exceeding all requirements of the building code, if applicable. (10) Whether or not the sign is to be illuminated and the method of illumination. (c) Time for consideration and issuance of permit . The city shall process all sign permit applications within 30 business days of the city's actual receipt of a complete application and application fee for a sign permit. Revisions or amendments to an application shall extend the review period to 20 business days from the date of submission of the revision or amendment. Revisions or amendments received after the issuance of a permit shall constitute a new application. (1) The city clerk or designee shall reject any application as incomplete that does not include all items required for a sign permit application as set forth under subsection (b) of this section. (2) The city clerk or designee shall reject any application containing any false material statements or omissions. Any rejected application later resubmitted shall be deemed to have been submitted on the date of resubmission instead of the original date of submission. (3) Within 30 business days of receipt of a complete application, the city clerk or designee shall: a. Issue the permit; or b. Inform the applicant in writing of the reasons why the permit cannot be issued. (4) Upon determination that the application fully complies with the provisions of this chapter, the building code, and all other applicable laws, regulations and chapters of the city code, the sign permit shall be issued by the city clerk or designee. (5) If it is determined that the application does not fully comply with the provisions of this chapter, the building code and all other applicable laws, regulations and chapters of the city code, the city clerk shall reject the application and notify the applicant of the decision and reason(s) for denial of the permit. The city clerk or designee shall give such notice in writing by hand-delivery, certified mail, e-mail or fax using the contact information provided on the application. The notice shall be post-marked or otherwise date-stamped on or before the 30th business day following the date of the completed application's receipt by the city. A denial pursuant to this section shall be appealable pursuant to the appeal procedures of this chapter. (6) If the city fails to act on an application for a sign permit within 30 business days, then the permit shall be deemed to have been granted. (7) Should it be determined that a sign permit was issued pursuant to an incomplete application, an application containing a false material statement, or otherwise erroneously issued in violation of this or other chapters of the city code, the city clerk or designee shall revoke the subject sign permit and the subject sign shall be removed. A revocation pursuant to this section shall be appealable pursuant to the appeal procedures of this chapter. (d) Permit fees . A sign permit shall not be issued unless the appropriate permit fees, as established by the city council, have been paid. No refunds of permit fees will be made for sign permits that expired due to failure to erect the subject sign. If a person desires to erect a sign in the same location as for an expired permit, a new application must first be processed and another fee paid in accordance with the fee schedule applicable at such time. (e) Expiration of permit . A sign permit shall become null and void if the sign for which the permit was issued has not been completed and fully installed within six months of the date of issuance, provided, however, that a 90-day extension shall be granted if a written request for extension is received by the city clerk or designee prior to the expiration date of the initial permit. (f) Appeals . A person whose permit application has been denied or a permitee whose permit has been revoked pursuant to this section may appeal the decision of the city clerk or designee to the city council upon filing a written notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten business days of the city clerk or designee's decision. The written notice of appeal shall state the alleged error made by the city clerk or designee in denying or revoking the permit. Such appeal shall be considered by the council at its next regularly scheduled meeting, provided that the notice of appeal is received by the city clerk a minimum of five full business days before the meeting. The city council shall make a final decision no later than the next regularly scheduled meeting following the meeting at which the appeal is initially considered. The city clerk or designee shall provide notice of the decision of the city council in writing by hand-delivery, certified mail, e-mail or fax using the contact information provided on the application. The notice shall be post-marked or otherwise date-stamped on or before the fifth business day following the date of the action by the city council. (g) Certiorari . In the event a person whose permit is denied or revoked is dissatisfied with the decision of the city council, they may petition for writ of certiorari to the Superior Court of Gwinnett County as provided by law. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-7. - Flags. (a) All flags shall be displayed on flagpoles, which may be vertical or mast arm flagpoles. For non-residential properties, flagpoles shall not exceed the height limit of the applicable zoning district, or 50 feet, whichever is less. Flagpoles on residential properties shall not exceed 25 feet in height or the height of the primary structure on the lot, whichever is less. (b) The maximum dimensions of any flag shall be proportional to the flagpole height. The hoist side of the flag shall not exceed 20 percent of the vertical height of the flagpole when ground-mounted. (c) In addition, flags are subject to the following limitations:
(d) Each single or two-family residential lot shall be allowed one flagpole. (e) Each multi-family, institutional, commercial, industrial or mixed-use lot shall be allowed a maximum of three flagpoles. (f) A maximum of two flags shall be allowed per flagpole. (g) A vertical flagpole must be set back from all property boundaries a distance which is at least equal to the height of the flagpole. (h) Flags and flagpoles shall be maintained in good repair, and to the extent applicable shall be in compliance with the building code. Flagpoles with broken halyards shall not be used and flags which are torn or frayed shall not be displayed. (i) On officially designated city, state, or federal holidays, there shall be no maximum flag size or number or other limitations on the display of flags. (j) This section shall not be construed to restrict the right to display eligible flags as banners as provided elsewhere in this article. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-8. - Sign standards for single and two-family residential land uses. (a) The aggregate sign area of all signs shall not exceed 16 square feet per lot with no individual sign to exceed six square feet in face area. Flags, banners and residential project entrance signs are excluded from the aggregate sign area limitation. (b) Signs shall not exceed five feet in height and shall be located a minimum of ten feet from the edge of a public street. (c) Except for residential project entrance signs, signs shall not be illuminated. (d) Building signs are prohibited. (e) Changeable copy signs are prohibited. (f) Flags and banners are permitted in accordance with Sections 62-8 and 62-14, respectively. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-9. - Sign standards for multi-family land uses. (a) The aggregate sign area of all signs shall be limited to six square feet per dwelling unit not to exceed 100 square feet total for the lot. Flags, banners and residential project entrance signs are excluded from the aggregate sign area limitation. (b) Principal freestanding signs shall not exceed 36 square feet or six feet in height and shall be located a minimum of 15 feet from the edge of a street or two feet behind the right-of-way, whichever is greater. (c) Miscellaneous freestanding signs shall be limited to two per driveway, no more than three square feet of face area and 2½ feet (30 inches) in height. Miscellaneous signs shall be located within three feet of a driveway and outside the public street right-of-way. (d) Except for residential project entrance signs, signs shall not be illuminated. (e) Building signs shall be limited to one per building, not to exceed four square feet. (f) Changeable copy signs are prohibited. (g) Flags and banners are permitted in accordance with sections 62-8 and 62-14, respectively. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-10. - Sign standards for institutional land uses. The provisions of this section apply to institutional uses that are single establishments on an individual lot or parcel. For institutional entities that occupy tenant space within a planned commercial, industrial or mixed use center shall be governed by section 62-12. (a) The aggregate sign area shall not exceed 100 square feet. (b) One principal freestanding sign per road frontage. (c) All principal freestanding signs shall be monument style only. (d) Principal freestanding signs shall be limited in face area and height as indicated in the table below and shall be located a minimum of 15 feet from the edge of a street or two feet behind the right-of-way, whichever is greater and at least 30 feet from the intersecting point of two street right-of-way lines.
(e) Miscellaneous freestanding signs shall be limited to two per driveway, no more than three square feet of face area and 2½ feet (30 inches) in height. Miscellaneous signs shall be located within three feet of a driveway and outside the public street right-of-way. (f) Signs shall not be internally illuminated. (g) Up to a maximum of 25 percent of the face area of the principal freestanding sign may be changeable copy. (h) Automatic changeable copy signs are prohibited. (i) Building signs shall be limited to 24 square feet of total face area, no more than two per building elevation and no individual sign to exceed 12 square feet. (j) Flags and banners are permitted in accordance with sections 62-8 and 62-14, respectively. (k) In lieu of allowed principal freestanding signs, an institutional use may elect to construct a residential project entrance sign subject to the standards contained in section 62-13(a). (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-11. - Sign standards for commercial, industrial and mixed land uses. (a) Building signs. Building signs for commercial, industrial or mixed uses are subject to the following restrictions: (1) The maximum sign area allowed on each building elevation visible from a public or private street is as follows: a. For single-occupant buildings (or multiple tenants sharing common space), the maximum allowed area for a principal building sign shall be in accordance with the table following subsection (b) of this section. b. For planned centers, the maximum allowed area for a principal building sign for each business or tenant on the exterior wall having the tenant's primary public entrance shall be in accordance with the table following subsection (b) of this section. (2) A building sign may not project higher than the wall or surface to which it is attached. (3) A building sign may not project more than 18 inches from the wall surface unless approved as a swinging or projecting sign under subsection (a)(4) of this section. (4) Swinging and projecting signs. a. Projecting signs shall not project more than 42 inches beyond the face of the building, nor exceed 16 square feet in area. b. Projections shall be at a 90-degree angle to the building face. c. All sides of a projecting sign shall be finished. (5) Miscellaneous building signs as allowed up to the maximum total aggregate established by the table following subsection (b) of this section and no more than two per authorized elevation. (6) Building signs may be of internal, external or halo illumination. (7) Changeable copy signs are prohibited as building signs. (8) Ground clearance under signs. a. Projecting signs shall provide a minimum of eight feet of clearance from ground level to the bottom of the sign. b. Under-canopy signs of greater than four square feet shall be rigidly mounted, and there shall be eight feet of clearance below the base of any rigidly mounted under-canopy sign over a pedestrian walkway. There shall be a minimum clearance of seven feet below the base of any non-rigidly mounted under-canopy sign over a pedestrian walkway. A minimum of 14 feet of clearance shall be maintained for an under-canopy sign above a vehicular driveway or service area. c. Awning, mansard and marquee signs shall be no less than eight feet above the ground when erected over pedestrian walkways and 14 feet above the ground over vehicular pathways at the lowest extremity of the sign. (b) Principal freestanding signs. Principal freestanding signs for commercial, industrial or mixed uses are subject to the following restrictions: (1) Maximum height shall be 15 feet. (2) Minimum setback is 15 feet from the curb or two feet behind the right-of-way, whichever is greater. No more than one principal freestanding sign may be located within the minimum front yard as specified by the zoning district applied to the property. No principal freestanding sign shall be located within 30 feet of the intersecting point of two street right-of-way lines. (3) Maximum sign area shall be in accordance with the table following subsection (b) of this section. (4) Principal freestanding signs located within 100 feet of a public right-of-way shall display the street address of the property. Within a planned center where multiple addresses exist, the highest and lowest street address numbers shall be identified. This section does not apply to any principal freestanding sign where the sign is located on property that has more than one street frontage and the property address is assigned from a street other than the street frontage whereupon such sign is erected. Street numbers shall be of contrasting colors against the background, visible from both directions of travel along the street, no less than six inches or more than ten inches in height. (5) Miscellaneous freestanding signs shall be limited to two per driveway, no more than three square feet of face area and 2½ feet (30 inches) in height. Miscellaneous signs shall be located within three feet of a driveway and outside the public street right-of-way. (6) Principal freestanding signs may be of internal, external or halo illumination. (7) Up to a maximum of 25 percent of the face area of the principal freestanding sign may be changeable copy. (8) Automatic changeable copy signs shall not change copy more frequently that once each ten seconds and the transition from message to message shall be accomplished within three seconds without effects such as scrolling, fading, sweeping or dissolving; nor shall such copy flash, blink or pulsate or contain any form of animation. (9) In lieu of allowed principal freestanding signs, a commercial, industrial or mixed use planned center may elect to construct a project entrance sign subject to the standards contained in section 62-13(b).
(c) Flags and temporary signs. Flags and temporary signs are permitted in accordance with sections 62-8 and 62-14, respectively. (d) Canopy signs. Canopy signs are restricted to two canopy signs, not to exceed eight square feet per side facing a public or private road. (e) Gas station signs. In addition to the gasoline service principal building wall sign, two additional wall signs, not to exceed eight square feet each shall be permitted on a detached car wash building that is an accessory use to the gasoline service station building. The detached car wash building wall sign shall be consistent with the color and style of other signage on the site. (f) Window signs. Window signs placed on, inside or outside of the window and visible from a public thoroughfare may not obstruct more than 20 percent of the window area. Window signs may be of neon type. (g) Double frontage and corner lots. Where any lot, parcel, or tract of land exists and has frontage on two or more streets, only one principal freestanding sign per road frontage giving access to the property shall be allowed. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-12. - Project entrance signs. (a) Single and two-family subdivision and multi-family project entrance signs . Each project entrance may have no more than one such sign per entrance if double-faced or two signs if attached to symmetrical entrance structures. (1) The sign structure must be constructed of brick, stone, masonry or equal architectural material and be monument style or integral to walls/fencing separating the project from the street. (2) The maximum face area shall not exceed 32 square feet. (3) The height of the structure shall not exceed eight feet including embellishments which shall not extend more than two feet above the main body of the structure. (4) Signs shall be located a minimum of 15 feet from the edge of a street or two feet behind the right-of-way, whichever is greater. (5) Signs shall not be internally illuminated. (b) Commercial or industrial subdivision or planned center or mixed use project entrance signs . Each project entrance may have no more than one such sign per entrance if double-faced or two signs if attached to symmetrical entrance structures. (1) The sign structure must be constructed of brick, stone, masonry or equal architectural material and be monument style. (2) The maximum face area shall not exceed 50 square feet. (3) The height of the structure shall not exceed ten feet including embellishments which shall not extend more than two feet above the main body of the structure. (4) Signs shall be located a minimum of 15 feet from the edge of a street or two feet behind the right-of-way, whichever is greater. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-13. - Temporary signs. (a) General provisions . (1) No temporary sign shall be located so as to block the view of principal sign or so as to create a safety hazard. (2) No temporary sign shall exceed the size of any principal sign relating to the same premises. (b) Banners . (1) Each banner shall not exceed 16 square feet. (2) Each banner must be individually attached to a pole, mast, arm, or other structure. However, banners shall not be attached to canopies, marquees, awnings, utility poles or be located within the right-of-way of a public street. (3) For any lot, banners shall be limited to one banner per public street frontage. (4) Banners must be maintained in good condition. (5) Banners shall be permitted only by issuance of a temporary sign permit allowing use of this type sign for a period of 21 consecutive days. A temporary sign permit may not be issued for the same premises at less than three-month intervals. In no case shall the same premises be allowed a temporary sign permit more than four times in a 12-month period. A fee, as established by the city council, shall be paid for each temporary sign permit. Upon expiration of the temporary sign permit, the permittee shall remove the banner(s) including any temporary supporting structure. (c) Sidewalk or sandwich board signs . (1) Each sign shall not exceed 30 inches wide by 45 inches tall. (2) Each sign must be located within ten feet of the pedestrian entrance of the premises to which the sign relates; (3) Such a sign may be utilized only during the hours of operation of the store or entity using it and shall be removed during the hours it is closed. (4) Sandwich boards are limited to one per tenant space. (d) Air- or gas-filled balloons. Air- or gas-filled balloons or similar devices, regardless of shape, which float above the ground and have a volume for air or gas exceeding three cubic feet. (1) Balloons shall be securely tethered to the ground of a building. (2) Balloons shall not exceed a volume of 115 cubic feet nor rise more than 40 feet above ground level. (3) No more than five balloons shall be allowed at a time. (4) Balloons shall be permitted only by issuance of a temporary sign permit allowing use of this type sign for a period of three consecutive days. A temporary sign permit may not be issued for the same premises at less than three-month intervals. In no case shall the same premises be allowed a temporary sign permit more than four times in a 12-month period. A fee, as established by the city council, shall be paid for each temporary sign permit. Upon expiration of the temporary sign permit, the permittee shall remove the balloon(s). (e) Festoons. (1) Festoons shall be securely anchored at both ends to the ground or other permanent structures. (2) Festoons shall be permitted only by issuance of a temporary sign permit allowing use of this type sign for a period of three consecutive days. A temporary sign permit may not be issued for the same premises at less than three-month intervals. In no case shall the same premises be allowed a temporary sign permit more than four times in a 12-month period. A fee, as established by the city council, shall be paid for each temporary sign permit. Upon expiration of the temporary sign permit, the permittee shall remove the festoons. (f) Inflatable signs. (1) Inflatable devices shall be securely anchored to the ground. Placement of inflatable devices on roofs is prohibited. (2) No more than one inflatable device shall be located on a lot at any given time. (3) Inflatable devices shall not appear animated nor exceed a height of 20 feet. (4) Inflatable devices shall be permitted only by issuance of a temporary sign permit allowing use of this type sign for a period of three consecutive days. A temporary sign permit may not be issued for the same premises at less than three-month intervals. In no case shall the same premises be allowed a temporary sign permit more than four times in a 12-month period. A fee, as established by the city council, shall be paid for each temporary sign permit. Upon expiration of the temporary sign permit, the permittee shall remove the inflatable device including any anchoring components. (g) Searchlights, beacons, laser lights and similar devices. (1) Devices shall project light upwards at an angle not less than 60 degrees from the horizontal plane. (2) Light sources must be shielded to a height no less than eight feet above ground level. (3) No more than two clusters of three or fewer lights shall be used at any one time. (4) Devices shall be permitted only by issuance of a temporary sign permit allowing use of this type sign for a period of three consecutive days. A temporary sign permit may not be issued for the same premises at less than three-month intervals. In no case shall the same premises be allowed a temporary sign permit more than four times in a 12-month period. A fee, as established by the city council, shall be paid for each temporary sign permit. Upon expiration of the temporary sign permit, the permittee shall remove the device(s). (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-14. - Nonconforming signs. (a) Continuance. The lawful use of a permanent sign existing at the time of enactment or amendment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may be continued even though such use does not conform to the provisions of this chapter. However, a nonconforming sign shall not be enlarged, altered, modified, improved, rebuilt or replaced. A nonconforming sign shall not be replaced by another nonconforming sign except that the substitution or interchange of poster panels, painted boards, or other dismountable material that does not change the shape, size or design shall be allowed. A change in the mode of message conveyance (i.e. from screen-print panel to LED) shall be considered a substantial change requiring a sign permit. (b) Maintenance and repair. All nonconforming signs shall be maintained in sound condition and orderly appearance. No structural repair shall be permitted except to make a nonconforming sign comply with all the requirements of this chapter or to render the sign structurally sound. To the extent that a nonconforming sign is damaged or destroyed by act of God or by other circumstances beyond the control of the sign's owner then such sign may be repaired or restored to its pre-damage condition without regard to the restrictions of this section. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012) Sec. 62-15. - Enforcement and penalties. (a) The city clerk, ordinance enforcement officer or designee may issue a citation for violation of this chapter by any entity, including, if applicable, the owner, manager or tenant of the of the premises on which a sign is located; for a sign erected, altered, maintained, converted, or used in violation of this chapter; or in violation of any other applicable ordinance, including but not limited to building or electrical codes. (b) Any entity violating the provisions of this chapter shall be an offense and punishable in accordance with the penalties provided for in section 1-8. (c) The city may seek affirmative equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to cause the repair or removal of any sign in violation of this chapter or other city ordinances. (d) The city clerk, ordinance enforcement officer or designee may remove any sign or structure illegally placed upon a public right-of-way without any prior notice and may dispose of said sign or structure. Removal and disposal of illegally placed signs shall not preclude the prosecution of any person for illegally placing such signs in the public right-of-way. (Ord. No. O-144-12, § 1, 6-21-2012)

div.head: Chapter 66 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Incorporation and powers, article 1: powers and construction, § 1.12; administrative affairs, article 3: administrative and service departments, § 3.10; judicial branch, article 4: jurisdiction, § 4.13; finance, article 6: franchises, § 6.14; service charges, § 6.15; collection of delinquent taxes and fees, § 6.18. State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40 et seq.
Sec. 66-1. - Purpose. The purpose of the rules and regulations contained in this chapter is to provide for the protection of the public health by prescribing the manner of storage, collection, transportation, and disposal of residential and industrial waste, rubbish, garbage and refuse. (Code 2004, § 12-101) Sec. 66-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Bags means plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed 35 pounds. Bin means a plastic receptacle with a capacity of approximately 18 gallons designed for the purpose of curbside collection of recyclable materials. Bulky waste means stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, furniture and other waste materials other than construction debris or hazardous waste with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for containers. Cart means a plastic receptacle with wheels and lid with a capacity of 90—95 gallons. City means the City of Berkeley Lake, Georgia. Collection means a person who, under agreements, verbal or written, with or without compensation, does the work of collecting and/or transporting solid waste from industries, offices, retail outlets, businesses, institutions, and/or similar locations, or from residential dwellings; provided, however, that this definition shall not include an individual collecting and/or transporting waste from his own single-family dwelling unit. Commodity means material that can be sold in a spot or future markets for processing and use or reuse. Each commodity shall retain its own identity and be kept separate. Commodity buyer means a buyer or processor of a commodity, selected by the contractor. Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. Container means a receptacle, excluding carts, for the storage of refuse and having a tight-fitting lid. The weight of a container and its contents shall not exceed 50 pounds. A recyclable container shall be clearly marked as such, durable in nature and with a hinged top which will not allow materials to escape while at curbside. Contract documents means the request for proposals, instructions to proposers, contractor's proposal, general specifications, the contract performance bond and any addenda or changes to the foregoing documents agreed to by the city and the contractor. Contractor means the person, corporation or partnership performing refuse collection and disposal under contract with the city. Disposal facility means any facility or location where any treatment, utilization, processing or deposition of solid waste occurs. Disposal operation means the performance of solid waste disposal, including administration, personnel, land, equipment, design, and other elements necessary or used in the work of solid waste disposal. Disposal site means a refuse depository including but not limited to sanitary landfills, transfer stations and waste processing/separation centers licensed, permitted or approved by all governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction and requiring such licenses, permits or approvals to receive refuse for processing or final disposal. Franchisee means a waste hauler authorized by the city. Garbage means every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable, and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay, or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains, or other animal or vegetable matter (including, but not by way of limitation, used tin cans and other food containers; and all putrescible or easily decomposable animal or vegetable waste matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents); except, in all cases, any matter included in the definition of bulky waste, construction debris, hazardous waste, rubbish and yard trimmings. Hazardous waste means waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United Stated Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal or state law. The term "hazardous waste" shall include motor oil, gasoline, paint, paint cans and items containing Freon or chlorofluorocarbons. Industrial waste means waste materials generated in industrial operations. Open dump means a disposal site at which solid waste from one or more sources is consolidated and left to decompose, burn, or to otherwise create environmental pollution or nuisance. Producer means an occupant of a residential unit who generates refuse. Putrescible wastes means wastes that are capable of being decomposed by microorganisms, including kitchen wastes, manure, offal, hatchery and poultry wastes, and garbage. Reclamation means a controlled method of sorting and storing solid wastes for future use in accordance with an approved plan. Recyclable material. (1) Newsprint; (2) Brown, clear and green glass and jars; (3) Aluminum and bimetal cans; and (4) HDPE clear plastic milk jugs and PET plastic soft drink containers. Refuse means all garbage, rubbish and yard trimmings generated by a producer. Residential unit means an occupied dwelling, whether a single-family home or a multifamily unit, within the corporate limits of the city requiring curbside collection. Rubbish means all chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging or wrapping, crockery or glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other similar waste materials not included in the definition of bulky waste, construction debris, garbage, hazardous waste and yard trimmings. Sanitary landfilling means a method of disposing of putrescible waste and/or hazardous waste and/or hazardous waste on land by placing an earth cover thereon. Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded waste materials. Solid waste means putrescible and nonputrescible wastes, except water-carried body wastes, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street refuse, dead animals, sewage, sludges, animal manures, industrial wastes, residue from incineration, food-processing wastes, construction wastes, hazardous wastes, and any other waste material in a solid or semi-solid state not otherwise defined in this chapter. Solid waste handling means the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing or disposing of solid waste or any combination thereof. Transfer station means a facility used to transfer solid wastes from one transportation vehicle to another for transportation to a disposal facility. Yard trimmings means all leaves, brush, grass, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping, development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Code 2004, § 12-102) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22. Sec. 66-3. - Enforcement. (a) Generally. The director of roads and public works shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. In the exercise of his solid waste management duties, said director shall inspect and regulate the operations of private collectors and private transportation and disposal systems to ensure that such operations are in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (b) Limitations of authority . All regulatory actions of the director of roads and public works shall be subject to the review of the mayor and council. (c) Appeal. Any person aggrieved by a requirement of, or a fee charged by, the director of public works shall have the right to appeal to the mayor and council, which body may, upon hearing, confirm, modify or revoke such requirement or fee. (Code 2004, § 12-103) Sec. 66-4. - Precollection. (a) Generally. No person shall keep or store solid waste outside of any residence or building within the city, except in proper containers for collection or otherwise prepared, as set forth herein or under the express prior approval of the director of roads and public works. Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. The director of roads and public works by written notice shall notify the owner or occupant of any premise with such solid waste accumulation to remove same. Failure to remove such accumulation within two weeks of the date of such written notice to do so shall be deemed a violation of these regulations and subject to penalties hereinafter set forth. A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or upon which such unlawful accumulation continues. (b) Containers. (1) All garbage containers shall be provided by the owner or occupant of each residence or establishment, by agreement with a franchisee or otherwise, sufficient in number to accommodate such waste generated by the residence or establishment between collections. Containers shall be of durable metal or plastic, watertight, nonabsorbent, rust-resistant, rodentproof, and easily cleanable. They shall be equipped with handles and tightly fitted covers and shall have a capacity of not less than ten gallons nor more than 35 gallons, except that bulk containers of a type accepted by the director of roads and public works as suitable for mechanical collection by authorized franchisees, such as carts, may be used for such collection. Containers failing to comply with these provisions or which have defects causing them to scatter waste upon the ground during collection or causing them to hamper or to injure the persons collecting waste shall be promptly replaced. (2) Disposable paper and plastic bags of a type, size and material designed for solid waste disposal may be used to contain refuse for storage and collection, provided they are unbroken, sealed, and loaded in such manner that normal handling will not cause the bag to open. (c) Rubbish. (1) Rubbish may be stored for collection in paperboard boxes or other throwaway containers strong enough to retain the waste; (2) Loose paper or cuttings shall be tied in bundles; (3) Rubbish containers or bundles shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight; (4) Limbs or cuttings shall not exceed four inches in diameter nor four feet in length; and (5) Rubbish containers or bundles shall be placed for collection beside the solid waste containers. (d) Placement. On days designated as collection days for the respective routes by the director of roads and public works, garbage and/or rubbish shall be placed for collection on the curb or beside the roadway in front of the residence or establishment owning same, or if the property abuts on an alley, at the rear of the property, but not in the gutter or in the street or alley in such manner as to interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic. Garbage, rubbish and recyclables shall not be placed on the right-of-way more than 24 hours in advance of pickup, and all empty containers shall be removed from the street within 24 hours after pickup. (e) Scavenging. No person other than the owner or authorized collection personnel shall sift the contents of or remove anything from containers, boxes or bundles containing garbage, rubbish or recyclables. (Code 2004, § 12-104) Sec. 66-5. - Collection. (a) Frequency. Garbage and rubbish shall be collected from residential premises at least once weekly, or such other frequency as may be established in the city's contract with the franchisee. (b) Collection vehicles. Vehicles used for collection and transportation of solid waste shall be kept clean and in good repair. They shall be constructed in such a manner that the contents thereof cannot be spilled, leaked, or blown from vehicle.
